title: Refraction - new critical angle when n2 is halved

content.question: Two transparent blocks are in contact at an interface, as shown in the figure. The top block is in the shape of a semicircle and is made from material <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of refractive index <math alttext="n sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The bottom block is rectangular and is made from material <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of refractive index <math alttext="n sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. A light ray is directed into the top block and is then incident on the interface between the two blocks. The critical angle at this interface is <math alttext="74 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>74</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, in that an angle of incidence <math alttext="theta sub i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math> greater than this results in total internal reflection at the interface. If the bottom block is replaced with another rectangular block made from a different material of refractive index <math alttext="one half n sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, what is the critical angle in the new scenario?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
